channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Greek clashes amid general strike
item.description: Greek protesters angry at the government's austerity policies clash with police, as a 48-hour general strike paralyses the country.

item.title: Turkey 'pursues rebels into Iraq'
item.description: Turkish troops are pursuing Kurdish rebels into northern Iraq, reports say, after overnight rebel attacks in which at least 26 Turkish soldiers died.

item.title: French woman held in Somalia dies
item.description: A 66-year-old French woman kidnapped from Kenya by suspected Somali militants has died, say French officials.

item.title: Army chief warns US over Pakistan
item.description: Pakistan's army chief Ashfaq Kayani warns the US that it will have to think "10 times" before taking any unilateral action in North Waziristan.

item.title: Researchers warn of new Stuxnet
item.description: Security firm Symantec has seen evidence that the authors of the Stuxnet worm could be working on a follow-up.

item.title: Egyptian defends Shalit interview
item.description: The Egyptian journalist who interviewed Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit just after Hamas freed him defends herself against Israeli criticism.

item.title: Bangkok districts on flood alert
item.description: Residents of seven districts of Bangkok are told to be prepared to evacuate as the worst flooding in decades nears the Thai capital.

item.title: MP quits role over 'spy' affair
item.description: An MP who had an affair with an aide accused of being a Russian spy has resigned from his post on the defence select committee.

item.title: Morales offers Bolivia road talks
item.description: Bolivian President Evo Morales offers direct talks as indigenous protesters reach La Paz after a two-month march against a road through the rainforest.

item.title: Russia signs free-trade agreement
item.description: Russia signs a free-trade deal with seven other former Soviet republics that will scrap export and import tariffs on a number of goods.

item.title: Chile students clash with police
item.description: Fresh protests by students demanding education reform descend into violence in the Chilean capital Santiago.

item.title: Viking boat burial find 'a first'
item.description: Archaeologists are describing a Viking boat burial find as the most important discovery of its kind to be made on the UK mainland.

item.title: Exotic animals on loose in Ohio
item.description: Police are hunting dozens of exotic animals on the loose in rural Ohio after their cages were left open and their owner found dead, say reports.

item.title: Internet 'may be changing brains'
item.description: Social network sites may be changing people's brains as well as their social life, research suggests.

item.title: Gerrard admits to career doubts
item.description: Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard admits he had doubts whether he would return from injury during the "hardest six months of my career".

item.title: Sportsday Live - breaking sports news
item.description: Sportsday Live - featuring the latest from the Rugby World Cup and the build-up to tonight's Champions League games, plus more.

item.title: Johnson speculation 'disgusting'
item.description: England flanker Tom Croft says it is "disgusting" that people are questioning Martin Johnson's future as manager.

item.title: Violence over Dale Farm evictions
item.description: Bricks and debris are thrown at police as officers move into Dale Farm amid violent scenes to secure the illegal part of the travellers' site.

item.title: Report warns on fuel-poor deaths
item.description: An independent report warns that thousands die each year from fuel poverty and calls for the definition to be tightened.

item.title: Fox attacks 'vindictive' media
item.description: Liam Fox tells MPs he should have been "more willing" to listen to "concerns" raised about his links with Adam Werritty - before attacking vindictiveness in the media.

item.title: Woman killed in club 'stampede'
item.description: A woman is dead and at least eight people hurt, two critically, as witnesses report a "stampede" as club-goers made for exits at a Northampton nightclub.

item.title: Tabak 'misread' Jo's friendliness
item.description: A Dutch engineer "completely misread" his neighbour's friendliness and went to kiss her before she screamed, a court hears.

item.title: MP blasts judge over Hillsborough
item.description: A Liverpool MP attacks a judge who called on the Hillsborough families to behave more like the relatives of the victims of the Bradford City stadium disaster.

item.title: Problems over carbon capture plan
item.description: The prime minister confirms there are problems with plans for a carbon capture power plant at Longannet in Fife.

item.title: Attacks threaten gritter service
item.description: One of Scotland's largest councils warns it will stop gritting roads in areas where its lorries and drivers are being attacked.

item.title: Murder accused 'knew abuse wrong'
item.description: The Jennifer Cardy murder trial hears that Robert Black told police he knew his sexual interest in young girls was wrong.

item.title: Aviva set to make 1,000 redundant
item.description: The giant insurance company Aviva is set to announce almost 1,000 job losses in the Republic.

item.title: 'No smacking is safe' - watchdog
item.description: The children's commissioner says there is no such thing as a safe smack, as assembly members prepare to debate a change in the law in Wales.

item.title: Deported men due back from Kenya
item.description: Two 18-year-old men from Cardiff are expected to fly back to the UK after being deported following questioning by anti-terror police in Kenya.

item.title: Gloves off at Republican debate
item.description: Republican presidential hopefuls' latest televised debate in the economically depressed state of Nevada proves to be one of the most acrimonious.

item.title: Apple full-year profits rise 85%
item.description: Apple reports 85% growth in full year profits but the shares still fall in after-hours trading.

item.title: Beauty queen denies drug charges
item.description: Former Colombian beauty queen Angie Sanclemente denies drug smuggling, at the start of her trial in Argentina.

item.title: Huge fine for anti-Chavez channel
item.description: Venezuela media regulators impose a huge fine on opposition TV channel Globovision, which says the government is trying to shut it down.

item.title: Botswana call to change gay laws
item.description: Botswana should decriminalise homosexuality and prostitution to prevent the spread of HIV/Aids, the country's ex-President Festus Mogae tells the BBC.

item.title: Africa 'set to grow 5% in 2011'
item.description: Sub-Saharan Africa is expected to notch up 5% growth in 2011, says the International Monetary Fund.

item.title: France begins Afghan withdrawals
item.description: France is set to pull out nearly 200 troops from Afghanistan in a few hours, kickstarting withdrawals announced three months ago by Paris.

item.title: EU regulators raid European banks
item.description: A number of banks across Europe have their offices raided by European Union regulators in an anti-competition investigation.

item.title: Yemen Nobel winner appeals to UN
item.description: Nobel Peace Prize winner Tawakul Karman is visiting New York to demand action from the United Nations to end the bloodshed in her native Yemen.

item.title: US links Bahrain arms to report
item.description: The US says it will wait for the findings of a human rights commission before pursuing a $53m (£34m) arms deal with the Gulf kingdom of Bahrain.

item.title: Six dead in Nepal aircraft crash
item.description: A military aircraft with six people on board which went missing in Nepal on Tuesday crashes, killing all six people on board, officials say.

item.title: US alert for India holiday season
item.description: The United States issues an alert for its citizens in India during the holiday season, warning them of "possible terrorist attacks".

item.title: Queen arrives for Australian tour
item.description: The Queen arrives in Australia for an 11-day tour of the country, ahead of a meeting of Commonwealth leaders in Perth next week.

item.title: Tibet nun 'dies in fire protest'
item.description: A Tibetan nun sets herself on fire near a restive monastery in western China, in the ninth such incident in recent months, reports say.

item.title: US prices rise 0.3% in September
item.description: US consumer prices rose by 0.3% in September, the US Labor Department says, with fuel costs seeing big increases.

item.title: China reduces holdings of US debt
item.description: China reduces holdings of US Treasuries to their lowest level in a year after credit rating downgrade by Standard & Poor's.

item.title: Bank united in favour of more QE
item.description: The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee was unanimous in voting for another £75bn of quantitative easing, minutes show.

item.title: Android debuts Ice Cream Sandwich
item.description: Google has unveiled the latest version of its industry-leading Android smartphone software.

item.title: Future chips could 'self rewire'
item.description: Future computers may have only one hardware component instead of multiple ones, allowing the device to rewire itself.

item.title: Warning over web security attack
item.description: A key web security system is no better defended now than when hackers undermined it earlier this year, says security guru.

item.title: Julian Barnes wins Booker prize
item.description: Julian Barnes wins the Man Booker Prize for his novel The Sense of an Ending, having missed out on three previous occasions.

item.title: Hathaway cast in Miserables film
item.description: Oscar-nominated actress Anne Hathaway is cast in the big-screen adaptation of hit stage musical Les Miserables.

item.title: Radiohead spearhead vinyl surge
item.description: Sales of vinyl albums in 2011 have already exceeded the total sold in 2010, with Radiohead and Adele the biggest sellers, according to the Official Charts Company.

item.title: Malaria vaccine trial raises hope
item.description: A malaria vaccine shows promising results in a clinical trial in Africa.

item.title: Reef fish live and hunt as a team
item.description: Reef fish work together to catch their dinner, scientists find, with one fish chasing prey while others block escape routes.

item.title: Med Bluefin tuna catch 'unabated'
item.description: Bluefin tuna boats in the Mediterranean Sea continue to catch many more fish than they report, a study concludes.

item.title: Egg donor compensation to rise
item.description: The UK's fertility watchdog has agreed to triple the compensation given to women who donate eggs to help infertile couples to have a child.

item.title: Swine flu linked to stillbirths
item.description: Babies born to mothers who contracted the swine flu virus faced a much greater risk of being stillborn according to a new study

item.title: Ruling 'threatens stem cell work'
item.description: Europe's highest court has ruled that stem cells from human embryos cannot be patented, in a case that could have major implications for medicine.

item.title: Shalit prisoner swap: Your reaction
item.description: Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit has arrived back in Israel following his release from five years' captivity, as part of a prisoner exchange deal. BBC website readers in the region have been reacting to the news.

item.title: 'Renewed deadly clashes in Homs'
item.description: At least 21 people, including civilians and police, are killed in renewed clashes in the Syrian city of Homs, activists say.

item.title: Spain's stolen babies
item.description: Spanish society has been shaken by revelations of the mass trafficking of babies, dating back to the Franco era but continuing until the 1990s involving respected doctors, nuns and priests.

item.title: Can anyone run a marathon at 100?
item.description: A 100-year-old Briton has become the world's oldest marathon runner. How was it possible?

item.title: Why would thieves steal a bridge?
item.description: Two Pennsylvania men have been charged with cutting up a steel bridge and selling it for scrap. Why is the US in the grip of a destructive rash of metal thefts?

item.title: VIDEO: Bangkok districts on flood alert
item.description: Residents of seven districts of Bangkok have been told to move valuables to higher ground and be ready to evacuate, as flooding which has swamped northern Thailand approaches the capital.

item.title: VIDEO: The Queen's final visit to Australia?
item.description: The Queen and Prince Philip have arrived in Australia for a 10-day visit.

item.title: VIDEO: Chile students riot for free education
item.description: Chile threatened to use emergency laws after another day of violent student demonstrations in the capital, Santiago.

item.title: VIDEO: Michael Moore on 'Occupy' movement
item.description: Film-maker and author Michael Moore talks to Jeremy Paxman about the significance of the 'Occupy' anti-capitalism protest movement, which began in New York, and has spread around the globe.

item.title: VIDEO: Ivorians on life after fighting
item.description: Robyn Bresnahan has travelled to Abidjan to find out how two families, one on each side of the political divide, are coping six months after post-election violence.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Models used as drug mules'
item.description: The trial has opened in Argentina of a Colombian supermodel, accused of running a drug smuggling ring using fellow models as mules.

item.title: VIDEO: Bahrain poised for rights report
item.description: After eight months of clashes that have claimed close to 40 lives, the Gulf kingdom of Bahrain is bracing itself for the findings of a major investigation into alleged human rights abuses, including torture.

item.title: VIDEO: Red carpet for London's Asian Awards
item.description: London's second annual Asian Awards celebrated achievements in the worlds of music, entertainment, sport and business.

item.title: End of Empire: Tough economy closes mining town
item.description: Why the sun set on an American town called Empire

item.title: Day in pictures: 19 October 2011
item.description: Striking photos from around the world

item.title: Australia appears at ease with arriving Queen
item.description: Australia appears at ease as Queen visits for 16th time

item.title: Why are La Roux and Example writing for girl bands?
item.description: Why are pop stars like La Roux writing for girl bands?

item.title: Joy and despair in Israel
item.description: Israelis weigh up price of freedom for Gilad Shalit

item.title: The disease killing Europe's plane trees
item.description: The disease that is killing Europe's plane trees

item.title: Search for answers over mayhem of riots
item.description: Panel meets public as it tries to make sense of summer rioting
